title.value: GitHub repositories with links to academic papers: Public access, traceability, and evolution
title.justification: The title explicitly states the paper's focus on GitHub repositories linking to academic papers, with emphasis on public access, traceability, and evolution.
title.quote: GitHub repositories with links to academic papers: Public access, traceability, and evolution

extractions.description: The paper investigates the relationship between GitHub repositories and academic papers, focusing on the public access, traceability, and evolution of these links. It conducts a large-scale study of 20,278 GitHub repositories that reference academic papers and analyzes the nature and implications of these links.

type.justification: The study involves a large-scale empirical analysis of 20,278 GitHub repositories that reference academic papers, examining the relationships and characteristics of these links.
type.quote: This paper investigates the role of academic paper references contained in these repositories. We conduct a large-scale study of 20 thousand GitHub repositories that make references to academic papers.

name.justification: The research focuses on the intersection of software development and academic publication, specifically examining how software repositories on platforms like GitHub reference academic papers.
name.quote: This paper investigates the role of academic paper references contained in these repositories.

name.justification: The paper discusses how scientific software is developed, shared, and documented in open-source platforms, connecting scientific findings with implementation.
name.quote: Traceability between published scientific breakthroughs and their implementation is essential, especially in the case of open-source scientific software which implements bleeding-edge science in its code.

name.justification: The paper examines the use and characteristics of open-source software repositories on GitHub that refer to scientific papers, highlighting aspects of open source development.
name.quote: Meanwhile, software that is developed during the scientific research process is often released as open source software (OSS) to promote reproducible research and increase the chances of having a stronger impact.
